argument: Sports is about pursuit of excellence and pushing limits in what the human body can achieve. Insofar as performance enhancing drugs do this, they are in line with the purpose of sport.
Regulating doping in any fair and comprehensive way is almost impossible, and therefore doping should be made legal so that all athletes are on the same playing field.
useing inhansing drugs is not insted of your biology. it only makes you reach your potential better. it is the only way to get to your potential.
Doping is now safer because more people are doing it and researching it
By making it legal, we can also monitor it, which would end the more serious problems of forcing people to dope against their will, and people overdosing because of lack of knowledge & supervision.
Gives more inspiration to people by seeing athletes reading higher achievements
We should legalize doping in sport because it is a victim-less crime.
Doping happens today in all major sports leagues anyway, but athletes who become addicted and suffer bodily harms are unable to report and get help due to the ban.
Prevents athletes from dying and disease because of more regulation on the use of drugs which happens anyway
If legal, sports such as the Olympics would be the result of human creativity and choice, not a very expensive horse race.
So many athletes are doping anyhow, we should just let them do it out in the open.
The quality of sports will increase since people will be physically better.
Doping would be healthier if it were allowed and could be supervised by doctors instead of hidden to avoid detection.
Doping allegations and punishment are often based on hearsay or rumor, which is can lead to false positives if its not allowed.

Even with the access to performance enhancing drugs, being a professional athlete still requires an immense amount of natural talent, so doping does not take away from the impressive nature of athletes' skills.
Legalized doping will create better and safer substance that is better regulated and better treated in the case of causing physical harms.
A lot of activities are far more dangerous than performance enhancing drugs and we don't ban those things, like bungee jumping or riding motorcycles.
Many of these drugs are used in medicine. Using them in sports will incentivise more research into them since sports is a very profitable field.
Insofar as athletes with access to illegal performance enhancing drugs and top doctors will always exist, it is fairer to legalize doping so everyone has access to these drugs.
Testing athletes will never catch everyone who dopes, which means some cheaters will always get through, it is preferable to just legalize doping for everyone.
We should legalize doping in sport because it levels the play field for people who have naturally lower hormone levels compared to those with naturally higher levels.
Athletes should have the right to do what they want to their own body, even if some worry it is unsafe - we allow people to do things that could hurt themselves all the time.
Drugs are just an extension to human abillitie like any other gear such as shoes or diving suits because they affect everyone the same, so legalizing them should be no different than legalizing shoes
In sport, harm is unavoidable, and so any claim that "druga are bad for the athletes health" is irrelevant, as the very decision of becoming a professional athlete is the decision to harm themselves.
The rationale behinds sports is breaking through the limitations on the human body, and doping enables this.
drugs helping the athletes to get to new records and this is way people love watching sports. more records = more jobs for athelets.
Steroids are often prescribed by doctors for recovery efforts, which can create false positives or push people out of sports if they need steroids.
Doping is not illegal. The sports management controls what is allowed for the good of the sport
Sport will be more interesting to watch once the athletes would be faster and stronger, therefore more people will watch sport and gain interest to practice sport themselves.
Legalizing doping in sport will open up entire new markets that will create jobs and motivate economic activity.
Legalizing doping would prevent situations in which athletes who are taking drugs legally for their health get punished (such as when human growth hormone is used post-injury).
Doping will enhance athletes performance and there for they will be able to break new records. breaking new records is an achievement that pushes athletes to excellency.

People enjoy watching sporting events in order to see records broken. Seeing as the human body has a natural limit, but medicine (and doping substances) keeps improving, it would keep people interested in sports.
Doping is happening anyway, but with regulations we can have athletes use less harmful drugs so there's less people dying because of doping
Already today many athlets use drugs, but these drugs are medically verified because they aren't regulated, which means the illegal drugs are more likely to harm the participants
Doping counteracts much more arbitrary factors in athleticism like genetic predisposition, thus making sports more fair by giving people a chance regardless of their genes.
Athletes who dope are capable of achieving greater athletic feats, which brings more entertainment for viewers and followers of sports.

People like to watch people perform superhuman acts. The use of drugs will significantly increase the abilities of athletes, will make sport more interesting and exciting and thus will provide greater enjoyment to viewers.
Switching from a full on ban to regulation is more enforceable than the status quo.
When we catch an athlete who dope we don't solve the problem because he may be one among many but we do lower the reputation of athletes and sports.
The government shouldn't regulate what you are allowed to do to your body
We should legalize doping in sport because the law right now is almost unenforceable, which reduces people's respect for the law, because it is so easily flaunted.
People watch sports to see professional athletes do great feats, allowing PEDs will make sports more entertaining.
Legalizing it would allow better regulation of the practice, keeping athletes from harming themselves by doing via illegal channels whose products may be unsafe
The illegal doping black market endangers athletes' lives, and it would be safer to legalize and regulate it.
Letting athletes to dope will allow us to examine what is the maximum human capacity o physical activity.
Once doping is legal, the amount of money and research invested in doping will grow significantly and within a few years they will be much safer then today.
We should legalize doping in sport because criminalizing doping leads to newer, more dangerous drugs that are not tested for replacing better studied and understood drugs.
We should legalize doping in sport because there is no compelling public health interest in banning doping.
It's already done, this would allow rule abiding athletes to compete on an even playing field
We allow people to use special shoes to run faster, drugs just enhance our ablities.

Many athletes need supplements in order to recover properly from training and injuries that naturally arise from sport, so legalizing doping would allow for the best treatments for athletes when they are injured.

Given the amazing advances in athletes' training, recovery, nutrition, and other physical therapy and treatments, doping provides relatively little competitive advantage compared to any time in the past.
We should legalize doping in sport because doping will go on either way, but if it is legal it will be safer and better regulated.
Drug testing violates the privacy of athletes who are forced to give blood and urine samples without notice, and that could be stopped if doping were legal.
Like vitamins, doping can be healthy in correct amount, sports give a controlled environmentto improve the field
If doping is legal, it will no longer be done under the table, so athletes will do it in secure environments with supervision from medical experts and team doctors.
We allow all kinds of technological advances in sports, so we should allow advancements in medicine, too.
Certain training and development activities are far more dangerous and harmful than doping but are used as an alternative.
it will bring more jobs to the primary industry that will help the aconomy.
The goal of sports is to reach the peak of human performance and test boundaries
Legalization of doping will increase the appeal of sports by allowing players to have more impressive accomplishments -- more home runs, more impressive plays, etc.
If they are professional athletes, it's their bodies, their choice.
For athletes, improving their achievements and winning competitions is the most important thing in life. For them to improve is more important than the long run effects of doping.
Just as we enable aerodynamic swimsuits or running shoes, doping enables us to test the true limits of the human body.
Doping is happening in any case, we we should accept it.
Every human has a right to do anything to himself, since it's no danger to others and therefore the state has no right banning him from doing it.
Doping correctly managed by legalization, will increase safety for himself/herself.
Countries use doping regardless since the drugs are hard to notice. Allowing all countries to use it will make the competition more equal.
It's a legitimate choice for athletes to make, just like becoming athletes in the first place
Doping improves preformance in sport and thus makes it more fun to watch. Athletes will make more money because of it.
We already have sporting events that use dangerous accessories to extend physical capicity (Pole Jumping, Skiing , shooting ranges etc)

Current methods of legally doping (like hypoxic tents that increase hematocrit) are much more expensive than regular doping will be after legalization, which will serve to make the same tools more accessible to everyone.

Legalization of doping prevents us from having to decide which drugs are too enhancing (for example, why creatine isn't considered performance enhancing while erythropoeitian is), which is a necessarily arbitrary process.
We should legalize doping in sport because it will allow athletes to recover from injuries and prolong their careers better.
The state can get money from taxation and export of these drugs
Doping will happen either way illegally - people just depend on not getting caught, legalizing it provides equal access to everyone which makes sports more fair.
By making it legal, we can also monitor it, which would end the more serious problems of forcing people to dope against their will, and people overdosing because of lack of knowledge & supervision.
We should legalize doping in sport because adults can make an informed decision with a doctor's help about what is best for them and their body.
Athletes know what's best for themselves and they know their own bodies better than anyone else, they can decide if doping is worth it for them.
The increased excitement about sports that legalizing doping will generate will cause more people to invest in teams, buy merchandise, and go to games, which is good for the sports industry.
The sport was invented to test the limit and today when you dope you can reach the true limit of your body
Legalizing doping makes sports fairer. Right now when a few athletes dope they gain a huge advantage which makes sports unfair, but legalizing doping evens the playing field.
It will level the playing field among those who dope to enhance performance and those who don't dope out of fear of retribution.

The rich would no longer command great advantages in sports because of their economic advantage letting them afford better training, coaching, and the like. Doping could compensate for resource differences.

In the status quo athletes buy their steroids from corrupt doctors or black markets where safety of the drug cannot be guaranteed, legalization creates regulatory bodies that will insure the safety of drug composition.
Legalizing doping represents an adaptation to new technology and is a natural progression of the rules in the same way that sport adapted to better athletic clothing and shoes.
Makes drugs more accessible due to technological advances and that balances between the highest achievers which are usually drug users to other less affluent athletes
It depends on what you mean by doping. Some "doping" is done with substances that are readily available to all athletes, so it is fair.
Doping becomes safer. When athletes dope right now they have to do it in risky ways, and don't go to doctors for help. Legalizing it encourages regulation.
As there is no level play , so let sportsmen have choice to to Mach in competition.
Anybody entering the field is willing to accept injuries on both the short & long terms to accomplish things while in their careers; the risks of doping are no different.
winning a gold medal in the Olympics will be possible for people who did not win the genetic lottery ticket.
Doping would allow athletes to maximize their athletic ability, and so legalizing doping would increase the overall quality of sports.
We should legalize doping in sport because it leads to a better media product compared to banning doping.

Sports are ultimately are businesses and should frame there decision making around what best draws the most views to make more money: doping allows for a continuous power creep fulfilling this burden.
Doping decreases the value of genetics in sports, allowing people who are not naturally large or strong to take part.
Doping is not different from various technologies such as tracks or clothes
The proposal will create equality in competitions. nowadays some athletes take enhancing drugs despite the bans and some don't, and that's unfair
Steroid use is relatively safe with the advancement of modern medicine, making its use far less dangerous than when doping was banned.
If doping were legal, the free market would regulate the prices to make it cheaper than when it is sold in the illegal market, this enabling low-income athletes to compete with high-income athletes.
Currently, doping does take place and often goes undetected. Therefore, the ban mostly means that athletes who play by the rules are less likelyto win.
The purpose of sport is primarily entertainment, and doping leads to more amazing performances from athletes, meaning that legalizing doping would improve the fan experience.
Human race will reach its limit dinner or latter but new drugs will develop endlessly , so it means that sport will get better endlessly
The infrastructure supporting anti-doping is incredibly expensive and wastes a lot of money and energy, requiring millions of dollars in testing and monitoring.
Doping is no different than other performance-enhancing techniques being used in sports today
We should legalize doping in sport because most people probably want better sports and thus democratic will supports legalization.
Steroid use creates a more exciting, competitive game for fans who are the most important part of the game.
There's no such thing as "fair" in sports, let people take whatever they want to get an advantage.
Trying to stop doing is expensive and futile, getting rid of the doping ban would mean less cheating and more focus on the sport.
Even though some doping drugs are dangerous, there are plenty that we know aren't, so we might as well legalize those.
Drugs would allow athletes to recover better from injuries so they can return to sport faster and won't be deterred of practicing sport in the first place
Athletes ought to be able to maintain their own bodily autonomy.
Using drugs will make it easier to get fit, so more people will participate in sports and get fit.
Legalizing doping makes it safer - it now unnecessary for people to dope under the table, which involves more health risks when people feel the need to hide it.
Allowing doping means more research into its health effects so if it is harmful we find out
There is a lot of money to be made in sports, athletes should be able to take drugs and do whatever they need to make that money.
We should legalize doping in sport because there is no difference aesthetically between improving performance with drugs and with newly-designed training and equipment.
Doping has and always will be something athletes choose to do, therefore regulating the drugs and the amounts used will serve to protect athletes from untested and unclean drugs.
legalizing the drugs will take people that sell it out of the crime cycle and in to the legale business that is also taxable.
Legalizing doping will allow legitimate top scientists to work on creating safer and more effective drugs where they are currently created by worse scientists willing to do illegal things.
Athletes already do so many things to improve their performance, so why not allow doping.
People should be allowed to do with their body as they wish, and sports organizations should not limit individuals bodily autonomy by banning doping.
Sports are about seeing how far we can push our physical limits and using performance enhancing drugs does just that - allows us to push the limits of our physical abilities.

Because doping is beneficial for athletes' recovery times, legalizing doping would allow for athletes to have longer, more productive careers where they can maximize the short window of their athletic peak.
As long as doping is illegal, the focus will be on making the drugs undetectable - but if it were legal, they could make the drugs safer.
There is no way to catch all the dopers, everyone knows it's happening, so make it legal.
Anybody entering the field is willing to accept injuries on both the short & long terms to accomplish things while in their careers; the risks of doping are no different.
Athletes are allowed to use most methods to increase their natural abilities (training), and doping is just one more way to increase what you could have.
Athletes already choose to risk their health for the purposes of athletic achievements. This is the rationale behind sports and doping allows them to achieve it.
The athlets will be faster because of the drugs and then more people will enjoy the sports because of the action.
When doping becomes legal, scientists and innovators will move in and produce better, safer drugs.
Players are unfairly left behind by cheaters if they cannot dope in sports, so they need to take drugs in order to keep up and maintain their salary.
It will average unreasonable differences due to natural talent.
Most people take interest in sport ( like the Olympics ) when records are being brake and adding drugs to sports meaning that note records will brake = sport will be more entertaining
More companies would invest in developing better, healthier medicine (and drugs) because now there is an active legal market for them in the professional sports industry.
Doping is a choice and athletes should have a right to make it. It helps them with a purpose they are dedicated for and means a lot to them.
When doping illegali the athelits are taking risks and are unregulated. When doping is legal we have better regulation and less overdoses of athelits
It is often extremely expensive to keep one's body in shape, so allowing doping would allow poorer athletes to compete.
The punishment for accidentally taking a banned substance is far too high and can ruin an athlete's life, it isn't worth it.
Most banned drugs are safe and used by normal people for injury recovery.
Likely to increase viewership and interest in sports, encouraging people to engage in them
Certain athletes are coerced by their team's leadership to take steroids and they should not be punished for this power asymmetry.
Doping allows athletes to push their limits, which makes sports more entertaining and interesting to watch.
It will improve the research on sport related injuries and help support athletes that have gotten hurt
Doping makes sports more interesting and thus attracts more audience that is likely to get inspired and do sports/achieve in other fields.
We should legalize doping in sport because it is arbitrary to reward someone for naturally having more of a chemical in their body and punish them for putting it there.
We should legalize doping in sport because it will drive down the costs of hormonal treatments that may be prohibitively expensive in the status quo.
Athletes have already approached the limit of what can be done with the human body alone, if we want any further progress in sports we have to legalize doping.
Doping by definition is using drugs that help your performance; any drugs that do more harm than good would still be banned, so no real harm is done.
Sporting events are entertainment events and the more athletes can do, the more entertaining the event is, so doping simply enhances the entertainment value of sports.
Because it is impossible to test every athlete, the only way to ensure a level playing field is through allowing doping.

The goal of sports is stretching the human limits and achieving outstanding results. We allow already unhealthy habits for this purpose: overworking, unhealthy diets, lack of sleep etc. why not drugs as well?

1. Doping is a choice: -People generally have the right to bodily autonomy. Especially athletes can make free and informed choice to harm their bodies through copious training. They have info through docs and internet.
We should legalize doping in sport because it will elevate the highest level of achievement and improve sport aesthetically and as an inspiration for people.
Professional athletes are adults who have the right to decide for themselves what they put in their bodies.
Athletes are adults who can make decisions for themselves and the state has no right to interfere.
We should legalize doping in sport because the purpose of sport is to achieve the best one can achieve, and doping facilitates better performance.
Removes arbitrariness caused by abilities and makes hard work more important and that's more inspirational
Doping bans can decimate teams who have already set their roster and lose their star player to a suspension.
Doping lets us explore the upper limit of human capability, which will allow players to play harder and beat more records.

Legalizing doping will let us shift focus from whether an athlete is doping to whether the athlete is maintaining their physical health while doping, which is preferable (ex. maintaining safe, if high, levels of testosterone).
Professional Athletes are likely to have a supervised doping regime, massively reducing risks
More people will be interested in sports since new records will be made.

It would enable regulation over the currently dangerous black market of substances, and less people would be hurt by consuming shady drugs, as after this motion all doping would require health regulations like any medicine.
Banning drugs doesn't work in regular society and it doesn't work in sports - might as well let people use them openly.

We allow athletes to decide risking grievous harm to themselves as part of the sport (head injuries in football, stress fractures, etc.). Possible harms from doping fall under the same category, and shouldn't influence legality.
Given that many athletes choose to dope anyway, it is preferable to legalize it in order to balance the competition amongst all athletes than to give some a competitive advantage.
Sport achievements are meant to inspire other people by pushing the boundaries of human capabilities, we should allow any means that help achieve that goal.

The ban on doping advantages privileged athletes with a greater capacity to hide their consumption of prohibited substances, while those without access to the technology and expertise required to do so are arbitrarily disadvantaged.
Legalizing doping will prevent future doping scandals around large sporting events and allow us to focus on the sport.

Many things athletes do hurts them physically. Running destroys your knees, weight lifting hurts the joints and generally the chances of getting wounded are very high. Doping do not produce significantly different damage.
Doping in sport enhance the pace in which athletes improve, therefore assisting in their motivation to train and in their diligence.
Legalizing doping will allow the government to regulate the sale and consumption such that they can prevent truly dangerous treatments and protect athletes.
alot of people in sports are already using drugs and we cant catch them. so by legalizing it we will equal the playing filled.
Using drugs is no different from the other advantages athletes try to utilize, such as wearing the best shoes and attire, shaving hair off their bodies, eating healthy, and more.
In the status quo doping happens but the government can't collect taxes, if we legalized doping the government will be able to collect tax revenue and put that into social spending.
The essence of sport is to watch humanity reach it's peaks, and doping helps in achieving that, just like special clothes or shoes did in the past
This would make sports fairer, since in the status quo, those who have the resources and ability to cheat and hide it have a huge advantage.
We enjoy sports because we like seeing athelits who are better then us, doping will improve the expirience of sports.
People watch sports because of the entertainment value, players who dope can play a more entertaining and intense game because they are stronger.
We should legalize doping in sport because it will allow women to compete at or closer to the level of men in sports where there has previously been an advantage for men.
Likely to increase viewership and interest in sports, thus increase funding to organizations that often donate back to communities (Sports associations etc..)
Doping rules are unnecessarily restrictive, leaving athletes to choose between their health and their profession.
It would make the poor gened people feel like they too can participate in sports, while today they don't bother to start because they think they weren't born with the right abilities.
People have the right to do things that harm their bodies if they deem that the outcome is worth it for themselves (such as choosing to drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes).
Allowing doping mean furthering human ability, making amateurs to further their goals and try to push themself further.
In the status quo, there's a big competitive advantage to cheating; now when everyone's doping, cheaters don't unfairly get ahead
The government doesn't have the right to ban doping since people have the freedom to put whatever in their bodies as long as they aren't hurting anyone else (like with cigarettes).

There is no morally significant difference between doping and other self-harms we consider acceptable for athletes to undergo, such as increased risk of concussions or other mental damage, and even a higher risk of death.
These bans are paternalistic, athletes who dope are adults and can decide for themselves whether they think that the additional athletic success is worth the consequences of the drugs.
Athletes consent into playing sports - if doping was legal and widespread, athletes would be aware of what they were getting into.

Bigger athletic achievements will draw in bigger crowds. Sport provides meaning for spectators by making them feel a part of a community of fans, with shared hopes and interests. The bigger that community, the better.
The health risks of doping are not meaningfully distinct from the normal risks of being an athlete, so a ban doesn't actually physically protect athletes.

This equalizes for arbitrary genetic differences which give some athletes advantages over others. Sports becomes fairer because athletes no longer can benefit from arbitrary conditions of their birth.
Illicit doping exists anyway in status quo, and is fairly dangerous. Legal and regulated doping will be much safer for athletes, and will decrease many physical harms to them that exist today.
Sports now becomes more fair, because doping allows athletes to correct for the random birth lottery - now, one athlete isn't better than another just because they were born with more testosterone
We should legalize doping in sport because it would let athlete who are coerced by their government into doping compete in the Olympics and other major events.
It will allow new types of sports to develop in the future ( for instance if a drug that will allow breathing under water, water soccer could be developed
Doping itself does not bother any other persons. So, we should respect such individual choices.
research about doping can reveal more information on the human body and there for help find new cures for physical illnesses such as Alzheimer.
Doping in sports would increase the amount of scoring, and raise the quality of sports by raising the quality of athletes.
Athletes have the right to decide on their own what is the best way to treat their body
If athletes want to compete drug free, we can create "clean" sport designations and consumers will get more choice of what to watch.
Some forms of doping that are currently banned could improve athletes' bodies, like blood doping to help them recover faster.
Doping is happening anyway, allowing Athletes to come forward reduces risks and gives them access to better healthcare
It stops the black market of doping that exists today, making athletes safer from untested drugs
It makes sport more interesting to watch because new records are constantly broken, therefore sports makes more money
Doping happens anyway and when it is illigale the sport is unfair to the regular athelits
As doping is very hard to detect on athletes we can assume at least some of them are already doping, thus creating an unfair disadvantage to law abiding athletes.
We should legalize doping in sport because it is unfair to impose one group's ethical standards for what is and is not fair in sport onto everyone else without their consent.
Some professionals Athletes are already using drugs so making it ligal makes the competition fair
